item.title: The Joys & Perils of Remote Working
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: In a change to the announced billing an impromptu early morning phone call made us think a chat about remote working might be in order. As many of us fight the January blues, and inevitable bout of illness that the new year often brings, it felt a timely opportunity to discuss the good, and the bad, aspects […]
item.content:encoded:
In a change to the announced billing an impromptu early morning phone call made us think a chat about remote working might be in order. As many of us fight the January blues, and inevitable bout of illness that the new year often brings, it felt a timely opportunity to discuss the good, and the bad, aspects of working from a distance.

Topics we discuss include:

  • How does working remotely affect us?
  • What we both you like and dislike about it
  • How much “real” work you achieve per day
  • The importance of “banter”
  • Is the reality like the dream?
  • A typical day for remote working?
  • Do we put extra pressure on ourselves to output more as we are not in the office?
  • How to feel part of the company you work for

And finally for those Nabaztag doubters out there you can read the full history of the internet enabled rabbit on Wikipedia!

Five Simple Steps Giveaway

To be in with a chance of winning one of the two sets of Five Simple Step’s Pocket Guide Collection 3 all you have to do it answer one of the following two questions correctly. Kieran’s decision will be final (he’s a harsh judge):

  1. Q: What was Matthew Lillard’s handle in the cult-classic 1995 film Hackers?
  2. Q: In the same year Sandra Bullock played a Systems Analyst in the film The Net. During the course of the film her identity is changed by cyber criminals but what is the name they gave her?

To enter just send a tweet to @backtofrontshow with your answer. We’ll announce winners on the next episode.

This episode is kindly supported by Five Simple Steps

Massive thanks to our good friends at Five Simple Steps who have kindly donated two sets of their new Pocket Guide Collection 3 for you to win. The questions are below — be sure to check out the show to find out how you can enter the contest.

Five Simple Steps books are not your average web design books. They are meticulously designed and published to the highest production standards with no compromise on quality and are built to last. With over 30 books to choose from in print and digital formats there’s a title for everyone.

http://www.fivesimplesteps.com/

item.title: Around the Web
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: Happy 2015! We are back for the new year with a look at four links that caught our attention over the holiday season. We also spill the beans on some of the topics we’ll be covering this year — in particular a series of discussions called #12ideas. Featured in this weeks episode: TechCrunch Cribs 12 […]
item.content:encoded:
Happy 2015! We are back for the new year with a look at four links that caught our attention over the holiday season. We also spill the beans on some of the topics we’ll be covering this year — in particular a series of discussions called #12ideas.

Featured in this weeks episode:

  • TechCrunch Cribs
  • 12 Startups in 12 Months
  • Just Try and do a Good Job
  • Moonpig Vulnerability

If you like our little show we’d very much appreciate a review on iTunes if you have time. Thanks!

item.title: The 2014 BAFTAS
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: It’s that time of the year when we look back on the past 12 months and dish out our (cough, cough) highly prized awards! This year in the 2014 BAFTAS we have eight categories and round off the show with a little bit of crystal ball gazing in which we both make our predictions for 2015. Without […]
item.content:encoded:
It’s that time of the year when we look back on the past 12 months and dish out our (cough, cough) highly prized awards! This year in the 2014 BAFTAS we have eight categories and round off the show with a little bit of crystal ball gazing in which we both make our predictions for 2015.

Without further ado here are the categories and winners:

  1. The award for not being a very good year in the industry: 2014
  2. Conference/event of the year: Web Teaching Day & Beyond Tellerrand Berlin
  3. Podcast of the year: Startup
  4. Most hyped app of the year: Slack
  5. Man of the year: Sean McCabe
  6. Woman of the year: Rachel Andrew
  7. Trend of the year: Privacy & Security
  8. Foo Bar of the year: #VATMOSS

Happy holidays to our all listeners. We really do appreciate including us in your weekly audio listening. See you in 2015.

This episode is kindly supported by Viaduct

Viaduct by aTechMedia has been developed from the ground up with developers in mind — deploying, debugging & scaling has never been this simple. Built by developers for developer Viaduct let’s you focus on the code whilst leaving the hard work of hosting to someone else.

Featuring all your favourite languages, a variety of databases and a great list of add-ons including e-mail delivery, Redis, Memcache, ElasticSearch, RabbitMQ and more Viaduct is well worth a look.

http://viaduct.io

item.title: That VAT Thing
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: This week Keir tries to speak “Somerset” and no surprises for guessing the outcome of that one. Once that’s done and dusted we take a look at the rise in Markdown based writing apps, examine a new ebook service from Liberio, try and fail to work out the implications of the new EU VAT place of supply […]
item.content:encoded:
This week Keir tries to speak “Somerset” and no surprises for guessing the outcome of that one. Once that’s done and dusted we take a look at the rise in Markdown based writing apps, examine a new ebook service from Liberio, try and fail to work out the implications of the new EU VAT place of supply rule for digital services and finally round it out with a chat about at a new comms tool.

  • Typed
  • Whiskey
  • Liberio – “eBooks to go”
  • Cat Noone interview on Smashing Magazine
  • Sendowl and the VAT question
  • Rachel Andrew on the VAT rules
  • Wire

item.itunes:summary: This week Keir tries to speak "Somerset" and no surprises for guessing the outcome of that one. Once that's done and dusted we take a look at the rise in Markdown (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown) based writing apps, examine a new ebook service from Liberio (http://liber.io), try and fail to work out the implications of the new EU VAT place of supply rule (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/vat-supplying-digital-services-and-the-vat-mini-one-stop-shop/vat-supplying-digital-services-and-the-vat-mini-one-stop-shop) for digital services and finally round it out with a chat about at a new comms tool. * Typed (http://realmacsoftware.com/typed) * Whiskey (http://usewhiskey.com/) * Liberio - "eBooks to go" (http://liber.io/blog/introducing-the-ebooks-to-go) * Cat Noone interview on Smashing Magazine (http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2014/10/10/interview-with-cat-noone/) * Sendowl and the VAT question (https://www.sendowl.com/blog/np-eu-vat-2015-proof-of-address.html) * Rachel Andrew on the VAT rules (http://rachelandrew.co.uk/archives/2014/11/30/how-the-eu-vat-rules-make-eu-startups-and-digital-businesses-uncompetitive-in-a-global-market/) * Wire (https://www.wire.com/)

item.title: Hacker not Cracker
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: We are back once again (albeit a few days weeks late). Illness, travel and house moves put things on hold but we’ll be back in full force in the run up to the holiday season. This week we welcome in our new logo courtesy of Sean Johnson and pick out four links and topical stories […]
item.content:encoded:
We are back once again (albeit a few days weeks late). Illness, travel and house moves put things on hold but we’ll be back in full force in the run up to the holiday season. This week we welcome in our new logo courtesy of Sean Johnson and pick out four links and topical stories we found of interest over the last few weeks.

  • Sean Johnson
  • Nomad Community
  • Yandex Browser
  • Bittorrent bundles
  • Sony Hack

This episode is kindly supported by aTechMedia

Huge thanks to the folks at aTechMedia for supporting this week’s show. You might be familiar with their products which include Deploy, CodeBase, Deliver and Sirportly. If you want to stay on track with code, issue tracking, transactional email deliveries and deployments their suite of tools are definitely worth a look at. We’ve been using them for years!

https://atechmedia.com

item.title: So Entitled?
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: As we reach the ripe old age of 30 we sit back and chat about a topic we often come back to over an artisinal flat white – why do people think everything on the web “should” be free? We discuss some possible causes, the backlash against app developers charging for previously free tools and […]
item.content:encoded:
As we reach the ripe old age of 30 we sit back and chat about a topic we often come back to over an artisinal flat white – why do people think everything on the web “should” be free? We discuss some possible causes, the backlash against app developers charging for previously free tools and ponder if the rise of big VC has played it’s part too.

Oh and yes there’s yet more microphone drama. All will be explained next week. As always we do apologise for the disruption to the service.

If you like our show please feel free to leave us a review on iTunes.

item.title: Around The Web

item.title: Transitioning
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: Just when you thought you could delete us from your podcatcher we are back and with a distinct lack of excuses for our absence. This week we discuss our new weekly formats and chat extensively about “transitioning”. Over the last few months both of us have found our main focuses shifting and as a result […]
item.content:encoded:
Just when you thought you could delete us from your podcatcher we are back and with a distinct lack of excuses for our absence. This week we discuss our new weekly formats and chat extensively about “transitioning”.

Over the last few months both of us have found our main focuses shifting and as a result the way we present ourselves online has changed, or had to change, too. We revisit our discussion on “flowery Twitter bios” and look at ways in which our friends, colleagues and heroes represent themselves online – through the blog posts they write, links they curate and share and other output including podcasts and videos. We touch on expectations, schedules and much more in our first episode back behind the Yeti’s.

  • Sean Wes
  • The Sean Wes Podcast: Episode 92
  • Daniel Howells on Twitter
  • Gary Vee
  • Gary Vee on YouTube

We’d love to hear about your experiences of transitioning. Get in touch on Twitter and Facebook.

item.title: Getty goes Free
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: This episode is generously supported by theweb.is — a new two day event curated by Craig Lockwood celebrating 25 years of the World Wide Web. On 30‐31st October 2014 16 of the web’s greatest innovators, storytellers and educators will be descending to Cardiff UK to tell their stories. We’ll be there, why not join us? […]
item.content:encoded:
This episode is generously supported by theweb.is — a new two day event curated by Craig Lockwood celebrating 25 years of the World Wide Web. On 30‐31st October 2014 16 of the web’s greatest innovators, storytellers and educators will be descending to Cardiff UK to tell their stories. We’ll be there, why not join us?

Six links and just under one hour of chat, what are we playing at? Variety is the name of the game this week. We discuss Kieran’s new event, Getty Images big news, magazine web sites, Netflix, coding standards, text editors and round off with the Mark Cuban’s best ever investment.

  • The Web Is
  • Indie Direct
  • Getty Images goes Free
  • Digest Magazine
  • Uppercase Magazine
  • Netflix 2014 European Expansion
  • Code Guide by @mdo
  • Atom
  • Huvr

item.title: Happy New Year
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: Like the proverbial phoenix we have risen! Kieran is back and we finally wish each other a happy new year. This episode we try and get to the bottom of why we weren’t nominated for a Net Award, this as you might imagine takes a while. We ask the the other burning question of the […]
item.content:encoded:
Like the proverbial phoenix we have risen! Kieran is back and we finally wish each other a happy new year. This episode we try and get to the bottom of why we weren’t nominated for a Net Award, this as you might imagine takes a while.

We ask the the other burning question of the week, that being is Harry Roberts (the one and only CSS Wizard) really under 25. We also manage to chat about some of the recent happenings in the web industry – no really we do. It’s good to be back.

  • Net Awards
  • Goodbye Editorially
  • 37signals becomes Basecamp
  • The Profitable Side Project
  • MK Geek Night All Dayer
  • Twitter for Machines
  • Ownercamp
  • Flappy Birds MMO

item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: It’s the end of year Back to Front Show awards special. item.content:encoded:
It’s the end of year Back to Front Show awards special. An opinonated, and occasionally tongue in cheek, look back over the last year in which we celebrate the events, the trends, the people, the apps, the podcasts, the magazines and the books that have made 2013 a great year. We also have details of our first ever guest co-host who will be joining Keir in December!

Award Categories

Winners will be linked up in a few weeks time *

  • Conference/event of the year
  • Side project of the year
  • Podcast of the year
  • Magazine of the year
  • Book of the year
  • “Blogger who you wished blogged more” of the year
  • Hipster Web Site of the year (AKA the moustache wax award for web ingenuity)
  • Dog related tech product of the year
  • Team of the year
  • Man of the year
  • Woman of the year
  • Trend of the year
  • “And finally…” of the year

* We really want you to listen to find out!

This weeks episode is kindly supported by Squarespace, the all-in-one platform that makes it fast and easy to create your own professional website or online portfolio. For a free trial and a massive 10% off, go to squarespace.com and use offer code Backtofront10.

In this week’s micro edition we look at six great articles including a Medium post on proving your app idea with existing technology, the art of great support, Grunt, advances in wi-fi technology, Kieran’s latest bling accessory and a great post by our Texan friend Mr. Trent walton.

item.title: How Not to Run a Competition
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: In the 11th instalment of our artisanal hand-crafted high-fidelity podcast we prove that despite being able to bring up a LAMP stack in under 12 minutes we are utterly incapable of running a competition. Listen in and find out who the two, yes two, winners of Keir’s lunchbox are! We also discuss Keir’s (and Elliot’s) […]
item.content:encoded:
In the 11th instalment of our artisanal hand-crafted high-fidelity podcast we prove that despite being able to bring up a LAMP stack in under 12 minutes we are utterly incapable of running a competition. Listen in and find out who the two, yes two, winners of Keir’s lunchbox are! We also discuss Keir’s (and Elliot’s) latest publication called Digest, chat about a new design trend, shine a light on a new screencasting service and ask if online comments are dead.

  • Hired podcast
  • Sound Studio
  • Hindenburg Systems
  • Quickcast
  • Should all web professionals be able to code?
  • Appropriate design
  • Disqus
  • Hipster logo

item.title: The Problem of Overfunding on KickStarter
item.dc:creator: keirwhitaker
item.description: As the web appears to have gone on holiday we present a mixed bag of goodness on Episode 010. We lament the loss of one of our zero’s, Kieran brings forth the news and the funny and we engage in a almost academic level of discourse on the issues associated with overfunding on crowdfunding platforms. […]
item.content:encoded:
As the web appears to have gone on holiday we present a mixed bag of goodness on Episode 010. We lament the loss of one of our zero’s, Kieran brings forth the news and the funny and we engage in a almost academic level of discourse on the issues associated with overfunding on crowdfunding platforms. Also included – a bit of Startup talk, a new Mac code editor, the new Royal baby and our first ever competition.

  • Our new about page
  • An Event Apart lunchboxes
  • Keir on his Tom Cruise box
  • Insites: ConfShop
  • Macaw
  • Pixeli.st
  • Startupland
  • Crowdfunding sites should ban over-funding
  • Man Vs Raccoon
  • Royally Desperate

Lunchbox Competition

To enter the Back to Front Show lunchbox giveaway simply tweet the answer to the following question before Friday 2nd August 2013. All correct answers will be entered into the draw. If nobody guesses correctly the closest response will win.

Question: What is the height difference in inches between Kieran and Keir?

item.content:encoded:
This weeks show is kindly supported by Insites: ConfShop — A unique one day event for web workers focused on openness, sharing and learning taking place in London on Friday July 5th. Tickets are limited to 100 and are available for £125.

In this episode we tell you about our new “studio”, discuss the route to inner nirvana (no really), the “problem” of celebrities on KickStarter and ask whether Ghost is the future of blogging as we know it.

Thanks again to Handheld Conference for supporting this weeks episode. It’s a conference focusing on “big ideas for small devices” taking place in Cardiff, UK on November 27th – 28th. Grab your ticket today.

This week we focus on Yahoo!’s decision to ban remote working, executing ideas, deep dish pizza and automagical open source cocktails.
